page.title: 12ECOLOGY IN LECHLADE
page.content: { A WALK TO THE NATURE RESERVE. There are many flowers and much wild life in the{Edward Richardson and {Phyllis Amey Nature Reserve}plus a pike-filled lake, which was originally one of the first gravel pits in the Cotswolds. Digging in Lechlade ended in May 1984. From the hide we observed coots, mallard, and a heron. Outside we heard birds singing and we disturbed two partridges in a barley field. We saw blue damsel flies and found marsh orchids in flower. There were seed pods on the toad flax and veitches and we saw scarlet pimpernel and speedwell. We passed a field of poppies and noticed an animals lair. It was too big for a mole or rabbit, I think it was a fox hole. Adders are frequently to be seen. A mammoths tusk was recently found by Steven Woodward.
